Award.AwardTitle: A Toolkit for in Vivo Visualization/Modulation of Plant Cell Wall Polysaccharides
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Michael G. Hahn (University of Georgia)

CoPIs: Geert-Jan Boons, Harry Gilbert, Christopher S. King, Malcolm A. O'Neill, and William S. York (University of Georgia)

There are currently no tools that can be used for in vivo imaging plant cell wall polysaccharides and glycoproteins. This project will provide a set of molecular probes for cell wall polysaccharides in the form of single-chain antibody fragments (ScFvs) and carbohydrate-binding modules (CBMs) as tools for in vivo imaging of plant cell walls using microscopy. The specific goals are: 1) to generate, either from hybridoma cell lines or from carbohydrate binding domains, a comprehensive series of tagged molecular probes that can be expressed in plant cells and will bind to cell wall glycans in vivo; and 2) to demonstrate that the probes generated will permit the localization of diverse carbohydrate structures within living plant cells or alternatively alter cell wall structure by selectively disrupting polysaccharide incorporation into walls in transgenic plants. It is anticipated that the molecular probes generated during the course of this project will be instrumental to those interested in the dynamics of plant cell wall polysaccharides and that some of these probes will disrupt cell wall assembly and structure through their interaction with the polysaccharides/glycoproteins and serve as valuable tools to discover the functions of cell wall polysaccharides in the biology of plant cells.

With respect to outreach and training, project personnel will teach a one week course to be held during each summer at the Complex Carbohydrate Research Center during the tenure of the grant to teach polysaccharide localization methods to interested scientists. An explicit effort will be made to involve undergraduate students in the research carried out under this grant. The participation of historically underrepresented groups in the research will be fostered by recruiting undergraduate students through the University of Georgia Summer Undergraduate Research Program (SURP) (http://www.grad.uga.edu/outreach&diversity/surp.html). All students and post-doctoral associates will be closely mentored to encourage and foster their development as research scientists. Information about all antibodies, ScFvs, and CBMs generated through this project, will be made available immediately to the scientific community via posting to a web-based antibody database (http://www.wallmabdb.net). All molecular probes will be made available to the research community without restriction through CarboSource (http://www.carbosource.net). Plasmids and transgenic plant lines generated in the molecular probe function validation studies will be available through the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (http://abrc.osu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
All growing plant cells are surrounded by polysaccharide-rich primary walls.  Primary walls give shape and structure to plant cells, tissues and, ultimately, organs.  These walls are sufficiently strong to prevent the cell from rupturing, yet are also flexible and plastic to accommodate growth and to respond to biotic and abiotic stimuli.  There is increasing evidence that primary walls play important roles in the biology of plant cells, particularly in their development and differentiation.  Furthermore, plant cell walls are of great economic importance, due to their uses as building materials, sources of dietary fiber, animal feed, targets for novel biopolyers, among many other uses.  Thus, increasing our knowledge of the structure and function of the macromolecular components of plant cell walls, and how their synthesis is coordinated and regulated, is required to understand how these components interact to form a functional wall. 

Polysaccharide structure, unlike the structures of the other two major classes of large biological molecules, nucleic acids and proteins, cannot be connected directly to the genetic code.  Rather, polysaccharides are synthesized and modified by protein complexes, whose output depends on the composition and configuration of these complexes.  This has made the development of probes to allow scientists to localize polysaccharides in living cells and follow their fates as cells grow, divide and differentiate difficult, in contrast to nucleic acids and proteins, which can now be followed routinely in living cells.  The limited availability of suitable molecular probes has hindered advances in our knowledge of the variations in polysaccharide structures at the cellular or tissue levels and how the dynamics of cell wall polysaccharide composition and deposition change and affect plant growth and development. 

This grant sought to take advantage of two types of probes that bind specifically to plant cell wall polysaccharides and that have become available over the past decade, monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) and carbohydrate-binding modules (CBMs).  The current world-wide Antibody Toolkit includes ~210 plant glycan-directed MAbs that bind to structures present in all major classes of plant cell wall polysaccharides (hemicelluloses, pectins, arabinogalactans), except cellulose.  Carbohydrate binding modules (CBMs) are non-catalytic components of enzymes that degrade plant polysaccharides that have been identified as studies of these enzymes have progressed.  Both MAbs and CBMs have seen extensive use over the past decade in studies of plant cell wall composition, variation, and dynamics, particularly through their use as highly sensitive and selective probes to define the localization patterns of plant polysccharide sub-structures (epitopes) in plant cells, tissues, and organs, but can only be used on fixed (dead) and sectioned plant material. 

This project sought to generate of novel cell wall visualization tools by generating a set of molecular probes that, when expressed in plants, will allow the monitoring of cell wall polysaccharides in vivo.  Such live imaging, especially when combined with experimental perturbations, offers a powerful approach toward gaining insights into the processes that occur as plant cells divide, grow and differentiate.  An added bonus is that some of these tools may also serve as polysaccharide-selective agents to alter wall structure and thereby provide insights into polysaccharide function in plant cells.  Thus, this project will provide important and complementary tools to plant molecular geneticists, biochemists and cell biologists studying cell wall structure, function and biology. 

These goals were largely accomplished over the course of the funding period.  Specifically, in a proof of concept study, two CBMs were fused to a fluorescent protein tag and expressed in plants.  These tagged CBMs successfully bound to polysaccharides in living plant cells enabling their visualization in vivo.  Further, the parts of the MAb sequences responsible for polysaccharide binding were cloned from hybridoma cell lines and combined to construct 92 single-chain antibody fragment (scFv) genes.   A little over half of these were tested for retention of the binding activity and specificity of their parent antibodies, with about a third retaining this activity.  Of these, eight scFvs, again fused to a fluorescent protein tag, were expressed in plants and successfully labeled cell walls in living plant cells.  As predicted in the original grant application, the expression of some of these new cell wall probes caused changes in plant growth and/or development, while others labeled the walls benignly.  Lastly, in collaboration with other laboratories, we have fully characterized the binding specificities of about two thirds of the MAbs generated with NSF funding. 

Thus, we successfully created a collection of new, well-characterized polysaccharide tools for plant cell wall research that allow both the visualization of polysaccharides in living plant cells, and in some cases, the targeted disruption of their functionality in plant cells, allowing plant cell wall scientists greater insight into the roles played by plant polysaccharides in the biology of plants.
